content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Mini Metro is described as a puzzle game, but to me it is not. A puzzle game, to me, should pose the player with a challenge to which there might be multiple solutions, but the solutions are at least static -- a solution that gives you X points now, gives you X points tomorrow. Mini Metro does not have that, as each challenge consists of the random appearance of random city types, between which you have to draw metro lines, with random upgrades appearing ever so often. Your score depends for a large part on how the random elements appear. The normal game allows you to remove metro lines at a whim, and most players quickly discover a cheesy tactic in this respect which can increase your score considerably. Unfortunately, this cheesy tactic is a chore to pull off, so once you have discovered it, the normal game is no fun anymore. There is still the extreme challenge for each map, which means that each line that you add is there to stay. This makes the game a lot more fun, but unfortunately in the extreme challenge the influence of the randomness on the final result is much bigger than in the normal game, as you cannot make small corrections to deal with the appearance of particularly unlucky cities (which happens quite a lot). Finally, this game suffers from the fact that there is no "goal". There are no "solutions". You cannot say "I have solved this map". You can only say "I have been able to score 20,000 points on this map". The next time you play that map, you can try to beat your own score, but why would you? You probably were particularly lucky when you got your high score, and thus you are just replaying to see if you can get lucky again.Despite those negative comments, I still recommend the game. It provides you with several dozens of fun hours, until you have nothing more to discover about the game. Most maps have something unique which sets them apart from the other maps. But once you have discovered each map and found a way to get a score that puts you in something like the top 10% of the players (which generally won't take long), you are done with it. Don't expect this game to have lasting appeal. But the price is right for the amount of fun that it brings.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Obviously — in its beta stages — Mini Metro is a work in progress by a hardworking, dedicated young company genuinely listening to the consumer. But I'm pleased beyond recognition to be part of its maturation. The concept is simple: Keep on top of a rapidly expanding metro system in a wide variety of maps (with more maps on the way) by drawing your own "map". As new stations pop up, extend lines, reroute lines, add trains and carriages to existing lines, or pause the simulation, delete the whole thing and start fresh. Each game is different, and each time you learn a little more to add to your burgeoning strategies.My only fault is that the better you get and the longer the game goes, the tedium seeps in. But that's certainly no reason to choose a different map and see what new adventures await on that ever-so-tantalizing blank map.

												This is a slightly disappointing game. It revels in its obscurity, expecting you to understand its mechanics as it slowly introduces them. But it doesn't even tell you the *purpose* of the game. There are also some weird bugs, like when you're trying to move a wagon between different lines -- difficult to describe so I'll just say it's glitchy.I also find the game to be too difficult for its own sake. It's more akin to a simulation game than a board game, yet it refuses to give information about stations (such as expected attendance?), and makes it hard to plan your lines ahead.Overall though, there's a deep feeling of satisfaction when playing in endless mode after losing a game, and seeing the trains live their life. I don't know. I'm unlikely to finish the game, and I wouldn't recommend it unless it's heavily on sale, but I can't not recommend it either. So there you go, the thumb up is there for you, you sneaky b*stards.

												The game is too committed to minimalism. While that commitment certainly makes the game look pretty, it also leaves the mechanics obscure. I suspect there are some deeper strategic considerations that come into play when deciding which stations to connect with which lines, but the game never explains them at all. Random placement of stations on the maps also makes the various levels all feel pretty much the same. Sure, the rivers are in different places. But that's about it. content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Mini Metro is a devilishly clever game that uses straightforward and simple mechanics to immerse you in 5 to 15 minutes of increasingly hectic gameplay. Each round starts with lulling, zen-like ease and and music to match. As the game progresses and your transit systems becomes more and more complex the atmosphere slowly and imperceptibly shifts until you find yourself racing to pick-up passengers from an over-crowded station with the pace of the music matching your ever increasing heartbeat.Pros:- Easy to learn mechanics.- Enough different mechanics to offer variations in strategies approaches but not too many to over-burden the player with choice.- Great soundtrack and minimalist design.- Great for solo (trying to best your previous scores) or competitive (trying to top the leaderboards) play.- 5-15 minutes of play per round is great for a more casual gaming experience.Cons:- There can be minor bugs from time to time which may take a bit to get fixed but I've never experienced anything game-breaking and the devs are really involved in the community.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Just to note: I'm reviewing the Early Access version...Oh dear God!  I haven't been able to let this one go.  Okay, so right now there is no sound, no music and only two of the three game modes are complete, but I don't really care!  You see: the gameplay is right there already.  It couldn't be simpler.  Join the map's stations as they appear at random on the map with your available lines (you start with 3) - simple.  That's it.   Ha ha ha ha ha.........  Yeah, right!This game is maddeningly addictive, be warned!  I can't put my finger on why, but I can't leave the game alone.  When you are rewarded, should you take a new line colour, a tunnel or a carriage (yes, just ONE carriage so you'd best add it to whichever train needs it most - correct answer is ALL of them!  Too bad).  To make things more complex, there are rivers and your lines can only span rivers if you have enough tunnel points (you soon won't)!  And just as you sit back to admire your beautiful network of circular, triangular and square stations all running a seamless service - up pops a hexagonal, slice, star or cross-shaped station!  These specials only pop up once, and it really matters where you add these (because you'll soon have a lot of shapes crawling around your network trying to reach them).  At the end of each game week, you are rewarded with an extra locomotive, and a random choice between an additional line colour, a tunnel point or an extra carriage.  You'll actually need them all.  Again, too bad, so sad...The simplicity of the GUI is wonderful.  You can drag lines around, stretching them any which way in zen-like fashion to join up stations as they inconveniently appear on your map.  You can erase lines and rebuild (you'll do that a lot)  Your only goal is not to let any station become too busy - dead simple - except it  isn't!  Already there are tactics evolving in the forum for making temporary lines to shift the load, but that's rather like rearranging deck-chairs on the Titanic.  Your game WILL go down in a Game Over screen.  Get used to it - you'll see it a lot!  Despite this game not being finished, it is already excellent and worth that weeny £4.99.  I'm told that buying direct through Humble will also net you the upcoming Android version (I missed that one).  This is one of those rare gems that is hugely addictive, simple yet clever.  Can't recommend this one enough!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have a fairly low-spec laptop, and so when a friend recommended this to me, I was terrified it wouldn't run. Even with my crappy processor and such, Mini Metro is an absolute delight to play. It is very simple, yet beautifully complex, and as such I have really fallen for this little gem of a game. You start out with three stations, connect them up, and all of a sudden as soon as new stations come along the game begins to flower as its 'simple yet complex' gameplay unravels. Circle stations are all the more frequent as you progress on your map, and finding ways of connecting these to your busy metro without having two consecutive circle stations on one line quickly becomes a challenging task. (The words 'bloody circle stations' are frequently heard from my room)As each 'week' passes, you gain a new locomotive and can then choose between a new line, tunnels or a carriage, with only a choice between two of the three each 'week'. This element of the game does rather force you to have a strategic approach to your map, and if you do not make a wise choice, you may soon find stations are becoming overcrowded with nothing you can do about it! I love that the way you route lines is not finite and you can rejig lines however you may like if things begin to get complicated. In an odd way, this game has rather given me a new respect for the rail network in real life and how difficult they must be to manage in terms of overcrowding. A very smooth running, pretty game with all the (similar) technicality and strategy of managing a real Underground's overcrowding issues. My highest praise goes to the developers. :)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a fantastic puzzle game with a unique art style and some really challenging mechanics.  I've been following the game since it went into Alpha and it has changed significantly with each update, adding new features constantly.  The beta release added some gorgeous UI tweaks that truly make the game feel like a proper game.  Everything from the typography, to the minimalistic graphic style is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  I can't wait to hear the music, and sound effects when they eventually get added.  The gameplay consists of a mix of puzzle and transport sim, connecting various stations (each a different geometric shape) to one another.  Each station spawns various passengers, which need to go to their corresponding station (Square passenger goes to square station, etc.).  There are so many approaches that you can take to each level that it feels like an open world puzzle game, something i've never quite experienced before.  As the level progresses and the map expands more stations pop up, forcing you to constantly redraw your routes to add the new stations and passengers.  If that station becomes too overcrowded it gives you about a minute before a game over screen.Mini Metro is a refreshing departure from the typical puzzle game, one that can be relaxing, challenging and rewarding all at the same time, all while looking absolutely stunning.  What a fantastic game, can't wait to see what the developer adds to make it better.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												I fell in love with Mini Metro from the first time I saw it, when it was the result of the Ludum Dare compo. It had a brilliant strategy of releasing a web-playable demo (RIP Unity Web Player), a demo so good that you could simply play it there and not buy the game.But the guys at Dino Polo Club announced the Early Access, which I propmptly bought, as the potential with this game was really visible. And it did not disappoint. I am someone that is not much into narratives, but rich gameplay, and this is what this game offers: rich, profound gameplay.In Mini Metro, you are the planner of the transportation system of a very abstract city. Stations with specific shapes will pop up all around the city, and characters will pop up in those stations. These characters will wait in the station for a train to pick up them, and the characters's destination matches their own shape. You will be able to lay down the train tracks and, depending on the mode you're playing, you will be able to change them to accomodate a bigger volume of people. If too many people remain in the station, however, the station will overcrowd and a timer will start. If the timer completes, you lose.The best part of this game, though, is the soundtrack. You will not find it anywhere, except on Gameplay videos, as it is generated for all the action that is happening in the level: when characters pop up, when you change the lines layout, etc. The music is composed by the great Disasterpeace, so if you like his music, you'll love Mini Metro's music for sure.

												A fun little game, very challenging and beautiful. I got hooked on it for a couple of weeks, and is definitely worth the money especially since it has been bundled several times.It has a lot of hard achievements. The only problem is that there are still some weird bugs that can crop up that will work against completing them. For instance, I was working on a NYC challenge where I had one line doing a large loop covering the edges of Manhattan, and a smaller loop hitting about six stations  on south Manhattan. As one station started crowding up with passengers who only needed to travel to the next station on the line, I dropped an extra train on the track so that it would quickly pick them up. Instead I watched the empty train blow through the station without stopping. While this may be reminiscent of how some subways operate in real life, it is not how the game is supposed to work. (For the record I only had two other trains on the same loop, and the maximum is four on a single line.) Adding insult to injury, the next train which DID stop only picked up a few passengers and rumbled on about a half-empty. After that it was too late to save the game (over when a station crowds for too long). It ended a mere 200 passengers short of the achievement with no other problem points on a nearly full map. Aargh!!Rating: 8.5/10Excellent gameplay. Needs more bugfixes.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Mini Metro is a subway themed puzzle game. Not a true simulator, although it does have elements of simulation in it.A very simple game that lets you focus entirely on the puzzle without anything you don't need to pay attention to, the goal is to connect the stations and get the people to go to a station that matches their shape in an ever expanding city which just keeps getting bigger and bigger until you can no longer handle the influx of people.There are three basic shapes- The square, triangle and circle, and you begin your game having to ferry passengers who each are one of these three basic shapes to a station with the same shape. Square passengers to square stations, triangles to triangle stations, and circles to circle stations. You then get more stations to connect, you have water you need to tunnel under with limited bridges, and eventually you will get unique station shapes to connect up to your lines.While any triangle station is good enough for a triangle passenger, a plus sign passenger will only go to the plus sign station. This means that you will need to keep your lines connected to each other as well as to the three basic stations, and that you will need to figure out where and when to transfer passengers. Losing a game happens when the waiting line at a station is too long, which will slowly fill in a circle around it to show you how close it is to being a game over.Passenger AI is rather simple, but it doesn't need to be complex either. They go to their nearest matching station, using as few lines as possible. An trains pick up passengers as long as they get them any closer at all, even just a single station.Of note is that when a train goes both ways, passengers will not get in on the one that heads away from their destination, instead waiting for a train that heads the right direction.And once you're done with most of this, there is extreme and endless mode. Endless mode is a game without losing, so you can relax and build your subway system without worrying about losing. Extreme mode is similar to the original game, but where you can move and remove tracks and trains at will normally, they are locked into place in extreme mode.On losing a game you can continue playing in endless mode.In the end, it is a simple but worthwhile game to play. It doesn't have a lot of special mechanics, flashy explosions or incredibly detailed environments, but all it does have works towards the same goal - An enjoyable puzzle game you're sure to get plenty of hours out of.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Mini Metro" is like a cross between "Eufloria" and "Cities in Motion" (if you can wrap your head around that).  It shares "Eufloria's" zen-like ambiance, but primarily tasks you with creating subway lines from one location to another.  The map starts you off small with only a few locations (which also consist of varying shapes), but as time goes by, you'll be bombarded with new locations that you'll need to connect to your existing lines.  Passengers have a specific "shape" they'd prefer to travel to, so you'll need to make sure that your lines are running quickly and efficiently.  I highly recommend checking this little gem out, it has a lot of potential!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Review made 27/10/2014 - Beta 8 VersionMiniMetro is the kind of Early Access game that needs to be placed in the spotlight, leaving the rough, jagged and unfinished games behind. With many early access games I can play it for hours and begin finding errors, or getting ideas of how the game could be made better. And why not? It's Early Access! That's the name of the game, right?Then I played MiniMetro, and I expected bugs, crashes and a dire need for polishing. And, aside from the lack of audio, I found... Well, a brilliant game. There's already plenty of maps, with more to come, and the simplistic nature of the game itself is polished to perfection.This game places you in control of an entire cities' Metro network, ferrying civilians from Stop A to Stop B, as indicated by various shapes. So, for example, there could be multiple people at a stop wanting to get to a Square stop. They will get on the line that has that stop available. As time progresses more stops appear randomly around the map, each with different shapes. As stations demand more stops, you'll quickly ecounter the enemy of the game: over-crowding, which you'll quickly learn is as big and scary a final boss as any other game you'll come across. All you have to do is 'survive' the week to unlock more trains, bridges or routes to be able to satisfy the need of every customer. Once you lose, and you will, your high-score is how many passengers you managed to take from A to B, and the days your service was up and running. It's a very simple and fitting scoring system that leaves you with a burning desire to play again just to beat those numbers.As time goes by you will learn to love or hate certain shapes, with particularly rare shapes getting high demand, but being in a particularly hard to reach location. I have come out of many playthroughs wishing circles were never invented, and that Triangles are satan-spawn.The pacing is fast and challenging, the only reprieve you can find being in the Pause button. The art style is minimalist and simplistic, obviously reminiscent of an Underground map. The replayability is seemingly endless, with stations appearing at random locations each time, alongside various different maps each with their own individual high-scores.I love this game, it's worth every penny, and it should be considered a complete game with incoming updates as far as I'm concerned. While it's still in Early Access though, I will suggest one thing that would be nice but is not entirely necessary: Stats for each station/line to see how many passengers are travelling on each, allowing you to micro-manage everything much more meticulously.10/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								A decievingly simple puzzle game. This game puts you in charge of connecting railway lines to circles, triangles, squares etc and your job is to make sure none of those stations get over crowded which seems simple enough and after the first 5 or so minutes of play you will believe that this game is easy but soon you will realise that it is not all that easy as more stations are made and passengers are made faster making you think constantly of a better way of handling the situation at hand. Will you make annother line to take the load of annother? Will you add more trains to make one line more effective? Will you add more carriages to your trains so they can carry more? Will you add more tunnels so you can get to those areas on the otherside of the lakes? You will have to make all these decisions in this game.-Gameplay-The gameplay is very simple, you draw lines to shapes and deliver shapes to other shapes. You have to make sure no stations become over crowded or you lose the game. The score is determined by how many 'peeps' you have delivered. You will get a train and a choice between 2 upgrades at the end of the week, currently there are (2 Tunnels, a carriage or a new line) these get randomised each week and you have the choice between 2.-Conclusion-Overall the game has a great concept and is executed very well with only a few missing features. Music is a main thing currently not in at the time of this review but of course this will be implemented in the future. I give this game a 9/10 for being unique, fun, exciting and overall intense as you make those quick second decisions. I can see this game going a long way with the 'Wishfull' features that may be implemented such as 'Multiplayer' 'Scenerario Editor' and more. If you are looking for a game you can sit down and play for 20 minutes then this is definately it. I Highly recommend checking this game out especially for the low price it is at. Video:

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												It is the end of the school year and, as a school teacher, I ampretty much left with nothing to do while waiting for summer break. So, there is this day when I am done with clearing my seat (we were renovating our office) and was sitting with my Macbook Air (MBA in short) looking for something to play. My steam would not download any games in school as the school has blocked all gaming sites (IP I presume), even for staff, and I am too lazy to set up a VPN. My MBA could not handle anything that is too graphical (if you know what I mean), so I went and start Mini Metro. The game is minimalistic, easy to understand, and fun. It is simply connection lines, shapes and moving rectangles that are presumably train carts. There is nothing intriguing about it, yet it is simplistically attractive, bite size (a game last around 3 to 5 minutes) and an extremely effective remedy for symptoms arised from office boredom, such as yawning and drowsiness. After a couple of rounds, my boss, the department head, walked pass. She looked at my monitor, and asked, "are you playing a game?"It took me around two seconds to give her an appropriate. "Nope. I'm working on a set of powerpoint slides for my class." "Oh, okay." She walked away after that.Well, that worked well, except that I no longer have any classes after that. Still, great game for these kind of situations.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
 Mini Metro	 is minimalist puzzle game themed around mass transportation. The goal is to pick up and deliver passengers by connecting stations to your system with a limited number of resources based on trains and lines. With a design that is both sleek and intuitive, the game requires little in terms of explanation for a new player. It's so easy to pick up that it comes as a shock when the game suddenly crushes your pathetic metro system under the weight of cruel reality. Pros	 Clean, minimalist design that ties into the transportation theme Puzzles are easy to understand but ramp up in difficulty Randomized station generation offers replayability Advanced strategies are not instantly apparent and require some experimentation for those looking for a challenge Mellow ambient music lowers your rage as passengers overload your metro system Cons	 Crushes your dreams of being a transportation engineer Randomized station generation means some thematic elements are lost; ie. you won't be building the exact replica of the London Tube Maps are devoid of placenames to connect you to the actual cities featured in the game The game always ends with you losing; only solace is how far up the leaderboard you can goThe negative points about randomized station generation and lack of thematic depth should be taken with the caveat that these were obviously purposeful choices, made to elevate the minimalist design. I personally found the game very enjoyable and would recommend it to anyone looking for an interesting take on transportation games.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Mini Metro is a great game that has given me hours of fun. I bought it in a recent Humble Bundle for it specifically and after a few hours I'm comfortable giving it a thumbs up, despite the criticisms that I am now about to lay out.My first caution is that, while the game is well designed and enjoyable, its content is a little thin for the sticker price of $10. There are 12 cities, and while there are some unique quirks between them, the only other practical difference is where the rivers are located. Most end up playing pretty close to the same way. It will still take you a while to invent and explore all the possible strategies for building your metro, but after about 10 hours I found my interest waning as there wasn't much else to spice things up. The three game modes help in this regard.That said, what content is there makes for quite a challenge. It's a perfect example of a game that gives you a small set of tools that can be combined to make incredibly complex systems.I also see some room for improvement with the UI. I like the game's minimalist graphics, but the interface takes this a shade too far. There were a few things that bothered me:1. Trains/carriages are a bit hard to see, being the same color and only slightly larger than the tracks, and often obscured by other objects. It's very difficult to see where everything is at a glance. Something to help them stand out, like a black outline, would be a big help.2. The stations have the opposite problem. They stand out well, but they're all the same color, differentiated only by shape. It's easy to lose track of where specific stations are since many look alike.3. Some more feedback in the UI would be nice (at least in sandbox mode, if it would make things too easy on normal/expert). Perhaps some summarized info about each line, like number of passengers waiting, number of trains/carriages active, average wait time. There's a stats page that has some of this info, but it's on a separate screen several clicks away.4. Speaking of the stats page, the minimalist design doesn't work so well there. Having to mouse over each data point to see numbers does not for easy reading make.In conclusion, Mini Metro is a simple but deep game that plays pretty much as advertised. Perhaps a bit lacking in content for full price, but still a solid pick for anyone who likes puzzle/strategy type sims.Edit: The more I play this game, the more I crave more features. I love the challenge but it's actually kind of frustrating how many times I think "gosh it would be nice if I could do X to make my metro more efficient", but alas, X is beyond the scope of gameplay. This really is perfect as a casual, pick-up-and-play mobile game, but if you're used to more in-depth sim type games, proceed with caution.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of an intriguing little puzzler, Mini Metro. Mini Metro was officially released onto Steam on November 6th, 2015 by Developer/Publisher Dinosaur Polo Club and Publisher AGM Playsim. (NOTE: This was a review from a game in my own Steam library, it was NOT provided by the Developer and/or Publisher)Video Review:


YouTube™ Video: Mini Metro Review - Steam 

			Views: 310		

			Join the Echo Army ► http://bit.ly/1KD1iv3 Twitter ► http://bit.ly/1LiIQ59 Google+ ► http://bit.ly/1NZUKa1 Facebook ► http://on.fb.me/1M0Comd Buy Mini Metro on Steam:...		

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:Fantastic little puzzler. The art-style and music are enchanting. Easy to play, hard to master. Addicting 4/5The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:I wasn't quite sure what to expect with this little thing. A transportation puzzler. Open and run lines to maximize efficiency. Seems simple enough, right? Especially since this isn't crazy detail, it's just lines and shapes. You get rolling, and there's this catchy, soothing music that gets going along with your lines and station placement....next thing you know, you just can't stop! You've got lines going everywhere, you're hoping to level up then dreading the decision of which perk you want (More Tunnels or a Carriage? Another Line or an extra Locomotive?). It can get rather intense on you pretty quickly. There are different levels of difficulty, daily challenges, high scores, scenario unlocks, etc. There is a ton of replayability. The visuals and the music are pleasant, enchanting and beautiful. Very nice touch for a little puzzler, really. I also genuinely thought I would take issue with the $10 price point, but cannot see a problem with that. now It is worth $10. I keep going back. It is nearly impossible to play just one attempt. 4/5 stars for this one, gamers. It's so much fun, once you try it you will get hooked!  Happy Gaming!!!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Mini Metro 

			Views: 799		

			Mini Metro Is a Subway Simulation Time Management Strategy Game. Available Here: Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/287980/ HomePage: http://dinopoloclub.com/minimetro/ Join us at Twitter or...		

     Mini Metro is a line based simulation strategy/ time based subway system. The art style is simplistic, and the gameplay is basic. You are in charge of a city subway system, and are responsible for transporting people from one station to another. You lose the game if you let the stations get overcrowded. The game is time management based, with new upgrades available every week when you successfully complete a week as a reward. There are a multitude of different levels and content, and each map of mission has its own leader-board, which can add to the competitive feeling as you play.      There are daily challenges, which is appreciated, but there is no expected level of completion, such as 500 people transported. This I feel takes away from any incentive a player might have towards these goals. The leader-boards for these challenges show the top 10 people, but don't give motivation or incentive for what you have accomplished on a personal level as games are meant to be personal.     Another aspect that may only appeal to certain players is that the game states directly that you cannot win. There is no end game. The game keeps growing, with new stations, complications, and population, to the point that you will not be able to keep up. You will not be able to grow your subway empire, simply manage the time you have to the best of your capability. If you enjoy time management games, this might be for you; the game is very basic- a simplistic casual game for those who find casual games too demanding.     The game mechanically give you exactly what it promises. For the current asking price of $10 dollars, I cannot recommend it, but if it were on sale, and this type of game appeals to you, then go for it. This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watchif you are looking for a more in-depth review.Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here. http://www.youtube.com/c/SocioPsycho

Posted: February 18
Product received for free
												Mini Metro is one of those hidden gems that was destined to be hidden.The graphics are clear, crisp. The colours are used precisely and in a thought out manner. It's well animated too. The fluididty is perfect for this type of game.As for the gameplay: The premise is simple. You have shapes dotted around the map. Those are stations. Each station will have passengers pop up, all wanting to go to a different shape station. The goal is to get them there quickly and efficently without the stations filling up.Difficulty's added by the limited amount of trains and lines, adding new shapes and stations and also having to sometimes go through water with a limited amount of tunnels.It's difficult, I'll say that much. I completed "Deliver xxx amount of passengers" achievements, but I never managed to complete the more difficult achievements. So, if you like becoming efficent in a single game, then this is perfect for you.One gripe though: Everything's slightly randomized. Because of that, some runs are doomed from the start. Like for example I had to instantly spend a tunnel because the station was slightly touching the water. You can't really move the tracks, so that couldn't be done either. Overall:7/10(All games start at a neutral 5/10 and move up and down based on their pros and cons)

content:
Posted: January 15
												A truly wonderful game. Can be enjoyed casually (just link up your network at random) but there really are more effective strategies. Each city has a unique feel because the random features (station positions and type) may be tweaked to give different proportions of station types and proportions of stations of different types on different land masses. Also, some cities have unique features like the Osaka shinkansen (fast trains) or slightly different weekly choices.There are basic achievements for each city, which lets you work out the basic mechanics of the game. Then there are more demanding achievements, with extra restrictions like only having tunnels on one line, and a much more demanding passenger target. These require a more efficient network since your network will start to crack under the strain well before you reach the passenger target. If the earlier incarnations of your network (when you have most opportunity for radical changes since there are not so many passengers) weren't efficient enough, then you likely won't make it (although you might if you're very lucky!).

Early Access Review
								*EARLY ACCESS REVIEW*This is a really fun game.  If you enjoy looking at subway maps and playing an engaging puzzle game - then this game could be for you.  The gameplay is simplistic yet challenging.  As time progresses, subway stations appear "randomly" and you are tasked with connecting the stations to one another by drawing subway lines in any way you see fit.  Different stations consist of different shapes you'd typically see on a subway map (i.e. dots, squares, stars, etc.).  there are a limited number of trains, carriages, and tunnels at your disposal and every game turn (one week) you get to choose what you would like to buy.  Sometimes, it pays to buy an additional subway line to start a new line with or sometimes it pays to buy an extra carriage if there are a lot of passengers at your existing lines.  And always keep track of those river crossings with tunnels - make them count as you can only do so many of them each game (unless of course you buy more each game turn).  What keeps the game fun, fresh, and engaging for me is the ability to change subway lines as additional stations randomly appear - you are not stuck with what you originally drew.  You have the flexibility to continue to change and evolve your strategy and layout of your subway grid as time goes on and passengers appear in greater numbers.  This mechanic is what keeps the puzzle game aspect engaging - rather than just an exercise of draw some subway lines and sit back and watch the map come to life (which can be fun too!) Since the game is early access, they currently have London, Paris, and New York City to start with but there are additional cities (such as Sao Paulo and St Petersburg) that are greyed out but should be playable soon.  Also, sound is currently disabled and there are other game modes not enabled but this is something to look forward to has development continues.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								(TL;DR @ bottom)I've been playing the alpha versions of this program for a few months now. It's a very relaxed puzzle game, in which you link lines from different types of stations in order to allow passengers to reach their desired type of destination. As the game goes on the map slowly expands and adds/changes stations to force you to keep expanding/upgrading. I recommend just ignoring the score and let yourself just focus on trying to find the best way to flow the traffic for as long as possible. Mini Metro is great for when you just want to relax; personally it’s good for recovering from rage-inducing moments other games cause.Pros: -Simple, Zen-like game-Minimalist graphics that are spot on for the theme.-Easy to learn, plenty of ways to try and experiment with the growing map to keep going.Cons:  (Since the game is beta, these will likely change in time)-No tutorial yet, so most the ways you can interact with the board have to be figured out on your own.  -No sound effects/music. The music is simple to solve, but other audio effects would be nice.-If you’re still reading, 15 points to Gryffindor. (Bloody gits)My tip for figuring out the controls: Experiment of course. You can click-drag about anything (stations, ends of lines, mid-lines) you don't like, It'll Highlight/grey out if you can/cannot do something respectively. Currently, the lack of audio is a downer, but the minimalist art style (and Zen theme) go well with a bit of Jazz. Just start GrooveShark.com (or Pandora, etc.), theme search for jazz and hit play; I'm good for an hour.TL;DR = Very relaxing puzzle game. Art-style can draw you in. Simple to play, enough challenge to keep it interesting with little stress. You’ll have to provide your own music (I recommend Jazz).

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Mini Metro is a realy simple but fun game to play. In the game you have certain 'points' on the map, that can look like a circle, square, triangle etc. Those 'points' represent metro stations. From time to time smaller icons like a circle, square, triangle etc. appear next to these metro stations. Those smaller icons respresent a traveler who would like to go to another metro station. For example, a smaller triangle on a circle metro station, would like to take the metro to a traingle metro station. If the traveler steps in, it will not go out until it reaches a triangle station. But it will step over on a different line if it can reach such a station faster. When you start you will just have a few metro stations, and a few lines. Every week you get more lines / locomotives / carrages or tunnels. Somethimes you will get a choice if you want for example a new line, or a new locomotive. You also have different maps to play, that are named like cities, like London, Paris, Hong Kong. Also in the game you only use the left mouse buttons, that is everything. I would say a great game if you would like a simple strategy game, but you also start a new map very soon. Becasue you get 'game over' eventualy.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro. Simplicity at its finest.The idea is simple: get passengers from station to station by building railways.The UI is simple: Click and drag to draw railways through stations.The rules are simple: No more than four trains on one track, and if any station gets overcrowded you lose.From these simple principles emerges chaos. Sheer, utter, beautiful chaos - fueled by the ever increasing number of stations you have to cater for, and driven by hasty changes to your Metro to try and provide routes for passengers to take in order to get to their destination ASAP.And yet, despite how chaotic things get, you can still employ strategy and make reasoned decisions at every turn. At the start of a new game you might choose to stick to one design philosophy or another, leading to experimentation to see which is the most effective.This, coupled with the randomly generated stations, makes the game very replayable and, if you appreciate the slow pacing, very fun.Despite this, that's all there is to it, really. After 2 or 3 hours of play you've pretty much seen it all. I imagine, after a few more hours of play, I'll probably get a little bored. In my mind, it's something I'd return to whilst waiting to do something else - in a role similar to Super Hexagon.Highly recommended if you're looking for a fun little game to play whilst rendering a video or waiting to do something else.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Mini Metro is a very simple game, but that is one of its strengths, but for gameplay and as a stylistic choice. Anyone who's ever been fascinated by maps, and specifically transit systems, will love this game. It may seem like a niche interest but working towards making an efficient metro system can actually be highly addictive. The game is easy to start playing but hard to master, which is perfect when the ultimate goal is the just the tried and true persuit of a high score.Mini Metro offers a wide range of cities, some of which must be unlocked by scoring at a certain level on previous cities. Despite aiming for simplicty, there are a number of creative ways cities are differentiated, such as station type spawn patterns and different asset constraints.If the game were just this it would probably have limited longevity, but where it really shines for some is in the daily challenge. Once per day there's a random seed generated on a given map that everyone gets *one* shot at, and then placed on a leaderboard. This is great for those who are competitive but also don't want the hassel of setting up something more complicated or can't invest much time most days. Also great for just casual challenges in a circle of friends.Overall Mini Metro is a simple game with a set purpose, but nails that purpose right on the nose. If this game seems like your thing I'd recomend checking it out. If you're on the fence it still might be worth checking out when it goes on sale.

It`s a good stuff to take a leisure time if you don`t like FPS`s aggressive gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Mini Metro is a simple little and mildly addictive puzzle game. You can play it quickly - 20 - 30 minutes will usually be enough to play.  It is a game where you have to link different cargo supplying spots and manage the trains linking them.  You are building an Underground network trying to survive the hectics of a modern metropolis. All games you start end the same: after an increasing amount of cargo you cannot move on time, one of your stations will be overfull and the game ends.The maps are simple and reflect the colours of tube maps of the different cities you can play. I like the layout of the maps. The sounds are suttle and pleasing. Different deliveries make different little sounds, and is relaxing.If you are looking for a train simulation game, this is not it.If you are looking for a simple game where you have to create and recreate a system to optimally move different forms around (stars, blocks, rounds etc) - and look for optimal efficiency with the knowlegde that in the end you will never reach a status quo - it is nice enough.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I ran into this at PAX and was smitten immediately. It is so hectic and yet Zen and peaceful. Like many of my favorite games, it's more about what's happening in your head than what's on the screen.This is a traffic routing game where you draw subway lines to take little shape people to the matching station shape. People appear in real time, but you can pause and redraw your map at any time. You use little rectangular trains, a few colors, a few bridges to cross rivers.The art is straight out of the classic London Underground map. But you get to make the map, in a stylized but real world city with its geography (eg London, Paris, Berlin, New York).As you deliver more passengers, you meet the challenges of growth. New stations crop up in outlying areas, forcing you to take apart the ingenious system that worked so well before and think again. New shapes of passenger and station appear, making it impossible to service all shapes with any one line. But they will transfer along the shortest route, which means you want your trains to meet at some stations. Mix in a long haul train line? Maybe you want to add a passenger car to accommodate all the people that build up as it makes its slow way.The stations and demand are randomly placed every time. The gameplay is the same every time, but the random map constantly challenges your understanding of these systems.I'm having a great time with it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I saw this game on the summer flash sale, and it looked interesting, so I scooped it up. Boy am I glad I did! This is a fantasic, little, indie, strategy game where you are managing a subway station. Your job is to lay down subway lines to connect the different stations and get the different shapes (people) to their desired destinations. It starts off slow and progressivley keeps adding more and more, so you really have to think about where to place the lanes to be the most efficient. It's super easy to learn, but will take some time to master, and it's absurdly addicting. This is an early access game but complely 100% playable. There is no music/audio yet, but that will come out soon. They use a very minimalistic art syle, which adds to it's clean look and makes it easy to understand, however, a few things might need to be clarified. Hopefully they will add a small description for the different items you have to choose from between weeks. There are a few I'm not completly understanding what they do or how they work. The beginning tutorial is very simple, although they do not show you how to move tracks or divert them. I kinda found that out by accident, so hopefully they will expand on a few of these things.I also hope they make it possible to save some of your games/city tracks you have made in a future update.Overall this is an awesome little game, that is well executed, and 100% worth the full asking price. 10/10

												Ever had a Christmas present wrapped in plain paper? You opened the present and what was in it kept you occupied for hours, days even. Welcome to Mini Metro, very ordinary looking (and I didn't buy this for a long time because of how it looked, seriously) but if I had to describe Mini Metro in 2 words I would say Deceptively Simple. with all the emphasis on deceptive."I got this" you think to yourself as you link the triangle station with the square station and onwards to the circle station. Out of nowhere comes a diamond station and everybody wants to go there. So you throw down another line all smug-like and watch the numbers building.EZPZ!! 200, 300, 400, 500... Oh. What? I have no bridges? I''ll go around. 550... Wait. What? Why is that station overcrowding? Aha.. I'll just add a carriage. No?? A train then? Errr. Nope. Reroute, reorganise... Ahh that's better.... AHA, a new station. I'll just link that with the blue line. Oh oh. Can't cross... Oh. What do I do?? Aggghh!! Game over. You managed to shift 578 people in 48 days. Dammit. I'll try again....And again. And again. And again. And again...........9/10Game is on rails. Far too simple. Right?(Edit: Typos)

I can also confidently say that if Los Angeles were added to the game, a lot of people I personally know, as well as so many more people would become interested in buying Mini Metro for that reason. I mean, have you seen all the fictional Los Angeles transportation maps countless people have made over the decades? Well, if you haven't, believe me when I say that the ones on Google Images are only the tip of the iceburg. I really do feel Los Angeles is worthy of a spot in Mini Metro for these reasons, and I really do hope adding the city is seriously considered, because countless people would seriously love to see that happen. Thank you for your consideration!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												It's a thematic puzzle game with minimalist visuals and simple mechanics!The theme? Misery.You see, if you play Mini Metro only aiming to reach the minimum goal for each city then it's okay enough. Fairly short but the challenge is reasonable. Overall, it's passable.The problem lies in trying to push the game any further.Mini Metro relies mainly on RNG to keep itself fresh. Map layout for each city is always the same but starting points, station placement and resource availability are randomised. Being a puzzle game, that would require very careful balance so the player has sufficient tools to keep stations from overcrowding (the game's fail state) at least most of the time.Unfortunately, that's not the case here. Games start fairly slow with a steady increase in activity for a short while, before cranking the difficulty up to eleven absurdly fast with stations popping up far away on the edges of the map, population increasing like nasty cancerous cells and don't even get me started on those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ same-type station clusters always forming WITHOUT FAIL.Resources to deal with all the junk being thrown at once? You only get to pick one at the end of each week and the selection is limited and also randomised, which is clearly one of the biggest flaws here, since there's no reason to lock the player out of vital options in a puzzle game, especially when urgency becomes a constant after just a few minutes and they might desperately need those bridges to save an urban planning career from an early catastrophe but WHO CARES IT'S JUST WATER HERE HAVE ANOTHER LINE.For three weeks straight.You could try exploiting the fact that you can change the routes and replace the trains as much as you want (it's not a simulator in the slightest, after all) but, really, having to do that every 3 seconds to prolong the inevitable for maybe another week at best just makes the whole thing a chore to play and you'll end up looking even more pathetically desperate.Unless this game gets some much-needed rebalancing, it's not really worth it. Until then, for anyone looking for a challenging and fair puzzle game, Mini Metro is most definitely going to look like one big RNG train wreck.Yes. I'm so clever.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5
												There is a hell and it is circular. ---You will enjoy this game. I enjoyed this game. It is deceptively simple and allows you to cultivate your own preferred playstyle in the absence of any substantive tutorial and with an overly compliant difficulty curve geared towards early success. As someone looking to recline and take in some enjoyment, Mini Metro is sleek and superb - accept the invite and try it, and there's a number of solid hours of glee as individual levels are 'beaten:' with the player ultimately losing, or retiring, with enough points cached to earn an achievement. Mini Metro then politely deadlocks the door and insists that if you want to reach the high scores, to obtain the achievements which are (in this context) the only real signifiers of completion, you'll have to put up with obnoxious RNG and unfavourable spawns. You will  require  some kind of bizarre foresight to overcome the random placement of the map's stations: four of one kind a row, with the game neglecting to provide you in the weekly update (in-game-time) with the upgrade you require (a tunnel, line, carriage, or whatever it may be given the precise circumstance), and Mini Metro quickly becomes an unpolished turd. The fact that the most exclusive achievements are possessed by a fraction of a percent of the playerbase in the port of a phone game should be evidence enough. Mini Metro is fun, but more of a joyous minimalist idea than a polished, concise video game experience:  there is no win state except that which is self-imposed, and if your self-imposition relies even remotely on Steam achievements, then your win state is a monumentous gamble away. I'd have recommended this game for the first 6-8 hours I played it. Now I'm triggered, several attempts at one of the level's achievements later, and I no longer think it is worth the time: other reviewers have praised this game's reward structure, but I think it undeserving. ~

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Such a simple concept, and yet so much fun!  The graphics are absolute basic, almost comical, but that does not take away from the gameplay.  The interface is very intuitive, and I found myself playing immediately without even bothering to look up anything about how to play.  This game is relaxing, yet challenging.  You'll soon be trapped by the "next time I'll do it so much better" feeling, and before you know it you've been playing for an hour...Your goal is to connect the metro stations together.  New stations pop up at random on the map, and you decide whether to extend an existing train line to service that new station or to create a new line.  You can add extra trains, extra cars, and even extra-fast trains to your lines as the game progresses.  Use your tunnels and bridges sparingly, because you only have so many to work with.  Also, the total number of train lines, engines, and carriage cars are also limited, but you can choose which items you want more of at the end of each simulated week in the game.  When people have to wait too long at a station to catch a train, the game is over.  Simple, right?  Ha!  If only...After you've played a few rounds you begin to think like a traffic engineer.  How can I best eliminate this bottle-neck?  Should I add another line to short-cut between these two large hubs?  Or maybe just add another train to the line?  What about making a loop?  You find yourself trying all sorts of different ideas, and cursing yourself when a new station pops up across the river and you don't have any bridges or tunnels left because you foolishly squandered them early on to make an inner-city loop!Mini Metro has a calm, relaxed atmosphere, and it reminds me a bit of the original Railroad Tycoon, but in this game there is no real economy.  There's nothing to buy, and the supply of track is unlimited.  Your only real adversary is time.  You need to keep the people moving, and the trains only go so fast...  An average game lasts about 10 minutes.Tons of fun, especialy for such a simple concept.  If you liked Sim City or Railroad Tycoon, chances are good that you'll love this game.  And at only 10 bucks, it's pretty cheap too.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is ridiculously addictive.  It's a pretty simple concept.  You're creating a subway to get passangers of various shapes to their correspondingly shaped stops.  You have various train lines and a certain number of tunnels you can construct.  At the end of each week you get an additional train and one of a few options (extra carriage, extra line, extra tunnels). The actual gameplay is hypnotic.  As you work to make your lines work as efficiently as possible, more stops pop up. Your trains go back and forth or around in a circle on your track and it's simultaneously engaging and rather cathartic to see all the little passangers getting where they're going.  I can't wait to see what comes up in future updates.

content:
Posted: January 12
												I never write reviews, so that should be some indication of how much I enjoy and respect this game and it's dev.  It's an addictive real-time simulation of the Travelling Salesman problem, combined with a bunch of probability statistics, and with a graphical interface that is a work of simplistic beauty.  Oh, and did I mention the music/sounds?  They're pretty much one and the same, and I honestly think one of the more under-rated parts of this game.  It's literally as if the trains were generating the music.I've only had this game a few weeks, but have already racked up dozens of hours of play.  And I'd also like to say that from what I can tell, the dev is an upstanding, modest person who takes pride in making a good product at a fair price, listens attentively to users, and even appears to offer excellent customer support (he mentioned that the new build of the game won't run on an older Mac OS version, and offered refunds to anyone who wanted one if they were affected.  Whoever you are, you're a class act, mate.Oh, and as a Cities Skylines fan, I can say that Mini Metro has made me a LOT better at designing roads, bus routes, and railways.  So if you want to improve your C:S skills, this game is totally worth it just for that reason.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
TL;DR - Mini Metro is a top-down iconographic map-planning and resource-management simulation in which you build a metro system that somehow manages to pop new stations up at an alarming rate.  Your only resource is time, and you will eventually lose - the satisfaction in this game comes from creating a well oiled machine.  I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoyed building transport networks on Simcity 4 or find themselves building all possible city improvements in Civ just because they like to see the city doing well.This (as of writing) is a game in Beta, but still thoroughly enjoyable.  Your task is to create a metro network by facilitaing the transport of shaped passengers (circle, square, triangle, star etc) with the same shaped stations.  This is done by connecting the station shapes with a coloured transport line - a train will automatically carry passengers back and forth along the line's length.The difficulty comes from the fact that each station can only so many passengers - and once a station has been full for 30 seconds, it's game over.  This becomes more and more likely as the map progressively bigger, more stations are added, and more shapes are included - your only tools against this are earned at the end of each week; more trains, more lines, and more carriages.  To throw one more spanner into the works, each map contains a river which can only be travered through the use of 'tunnels' - again, only to be earned at the end of each week.  This causes  for some very difficult decisions to be made about whether you should pick more trains to add to your system, or whether you're going to need to get over the river with one of your lines before the week is out.The aesthetic mirror's the current London Underground colouring and angling - meaning that even when you end up losing the game, looking back over your map is a fairly satisfying experience.I definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys intense resource management and optimising pathing; the skill in this game is in weighing up many different routes simultaneously and evaluating which is the best.  An oddly satisfying experience all the way through; one that will be even better once the music and sound effects have been added into the game.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I ask myself, Why didn't I make this game?As simple as it may seem. YOUR WRONG. It is not simple at all and it really puts a different view in my mind about the people who made our train systems. The people who have to deal with us by working at that train stations, out in view and behind the sence. You have to think is it better to have one main place for everyone to be transfering like Penn Station on the north east side of the USA. Should it flow different like the BART system on the west coast of the USA. Sadly, it is not one or the other. Some place make changes all the time to better time and get more people around where they need to be.You could start off simple with one line or just keep it three lines but you may find yourself finding the people getting upset and the game ends quickly. A lot of pressure or maybe it is no pressure at all if you like puzzles and strategy. With this game you will have to keep changing your strategies through the game or maybe just in the beginning depending on how you read the game. Even how your draw the line between spots has strategy all on its own.I do enjoy this game. It is very relaxing to my engineer mindset which doesn't seem to turn off, this game makes it slow down. The music is calming as well. Personally, I am not sure if they change the music through out each different stations, but never the less, it does keep me calm. Plus it is so simple to learn how to draw between stations, my mother who hasn't toucch a computer since they did punch cards for programming, can understand it and enjoy it as well or help me play along.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												Mini MetroFirst of all I have to admit that I think this game is presented in a very appealing style. As an architect it is my day to day job to think about graphical appearances of drawings and diagrams so I see myself capable to state that the art and graphic style of the game is phenomenal. The greatness of the presenation starts with the use of pictogram's and symbols, includes great color management and concludes in a nearly flawless minimal design game.The game is a great "time killer" for optimizing fanatics because fully understanding the game takes quiet a while in my opinion as it is not a as straight forward game as it looks like in the beginning. Its not mastered by thinking "I am going to connect these stations and lets see what happens!". A situation which shows that there is more effort put into the design of the game than in a strait forward browser games. The game also has great balancing as each factor is important but no game factor has a ridiculous overwhelmingly impact. For example the drawing style of each player is different and the game sometimes draws the metro lines so that he trains actually lose some time on each station. If the player redraws and tries to put the lines in the right angel he achieves a optimization of some milli second. A factor that helps the player to make a better score but it is also possible to make good scores by concentrating on other "small factors" like the one just explained.Finally I have to also state that the game has an factor of addiction as the player always things "one more time, this time I'm going to make a score over 2.000". A situation (which again) shows very good inventing, designing and balancing potential by the developers of the game. So putting all together this game is totally worth its money as the player will play for a throughout great design and thought through little puzzle game.http://architectonreview.blogspot.com.tr/

												Mini Metro is a beautiful game to experience. In gameplay terms, it's easy to pick up but hard to master. For good 'runs', you'll need forward-thinking, adaptability and a bit of luck, which gives it a perfect one-more-try feel. Achievement-wise, it rewards both newbies and masters: half are devoted roughly to "beating" certain maps by reaching certain passenger counts, the rest toward map-specific challenges involving one bridge or limited lines/locomotives, some of which border on fiendish.With Workshop support promised by the devs in the near future, Mini Metro also benefits from frequent updates and a small but dedicated community. I'd comfortably recommend this at full price, and implore you to buy at any less.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Very nice little optimization puzzle game. The screenshots alone don't really do it justice. Each level starts off easy but then gets gradually harder when more and more stations pop up and passengers start to appear in a quicker pace. After each in-game week you get to pick one of two perks, such as tunnels or a new locomotive. These choices are interesting, there's no right answer that works all the time. The game also forces you to make interesting choices all the time in the name of optimization. Shorten that crowded line, but make another one longer? Add a carriage here or a locomotive there? Recommended, especially right now when you can get it in the Humble Eye Candy Bundle along with some other nice games. :)

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro, a strategy game by Dinosaur Polo Club that is so simple yet so fun, you’d think that they actually made a game equivalent to Sudoku.The game revolves around you, a bunch of shapes that resemble stations, train lines and customers that look like shapes. You have to connect all the stations together and get all the passengers to where they want to be without the stations getting crowded. The maps slowly expand revealing more play area to which more stations open up for you to connect to. You can make numerous train lines or add more trains and carriages to existing lines to help transporting passengers.There are numerous levels to play on, each with rivers where you have to make tunnels through, despite the limited supply. You get a train given to you every week and a choice of an extra tunnel, carriage or train line to get to help you win. Even though it looks easy, it isn’t really. They added an extra mode which is the equivalent of a sandbox mode, where the stations can get full of passengers but the game doesn’t end, this allows you to just build and deliver passengers as you please, while still working with the limited supplies. They plan on making another mode which will be hard-core, only for experienced players, more cities, customers but maybe less or normal amount of assets.Mini Metro is In Early Access currently (time of review posting) and therefore isn’t finished, a simple game with lots to do. Despite the lack of music, there are big plans for the future and it’s exciting to imagine what comes next. The game comes with the ability to change between colour-blind mode and not colour-blind mode, meaning that players who have trouble with colours can still play the game. There is even a Day and Night mode that changes the colour of the game, white for day and black for night so it doesn’t hurt your eyes. These two features aren’t given often in games but should be added for those who need these options.This game, despite its easy looks it is quite hard, and that’s something you don’t see much anymore, hard games that look easy. Dinosaur Polo Club have developed a game that is really fun and challenging, something that strategy game lovers need in their steam library.I rate this game a 9/10. Not a 10 because of the lack of features, but since it’s an Early Access game, a couple more updates and it’ll be a 10/10.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												The first thing you notice in Mini Metro is the clean aesthetic. The minimalist graphics are both pleasing to the eyes and reminiscing of the many subway maps we have around the world. That graphical happiness is soon followed by the pleasure of drawing the metro lines, in a very intuitive way. But then come the passengers...after a few minutes things start to become hectic and you're scrambling around trying to fix your network that is inevitably doomed. And then, you want to try it again to do better.But after theses first few games, you will begin to notice a pattern...the first few minutes of the game are boring. Setting up a basic network is easy for anyone with a few games under their belt. Even on fast forward, it still feels too slow...until it doesn't, and suddenly you notice your network has congestion all over the place. You fix things here and there, but usually once congestion start to set in, it will just go downhill. And now you notice the main problem of the game: pacing.Pacing in Mini Metro is weird. Things are usually either too slow, or too fast. The sweet spot, where you have to fix stuff but you still have time to think and do things coherently, is such a small part of each game. The endless mode offers some of the pleasure of doing things at your own pace, but it encourages a playstyle that is dumb (serving the minimum numbers of station, leaving 2/3 of the map unconnected).Another big drawback of the game is the randomness. Stations spawn completely randomly, and an important station spawning at the wrong time or the wrong place can utterly destroy a game that was going well. On the other hand, you can sometime be saved by stations popping up exactly where you need them. This randomness is both frustrating, and greatly limit the strategic aspect of the game. It's hard to know how well or how bad you're doing when things vary so much from game to game. Therefore, it's even harder to learn to play the game properly. Expert modes, challenges, or simply highscore chases can become very frustrating when you get bad stations spawns.All of that makes Mini Metro a tough game to evaluate. It's original, it had a good idea and great visual, but the minute-to-minute gameplay isn't quite there. I wish Steam would let me gives a "neutral thumb", but since i have to choose between a "up thumb" or a "down thumb", I'm gonna go with a "play the free flash prototype for a few minutes, but skip this full game version".PS: if you do play the full game, I recommend you cut all sounds (there is no option to cut only certain sounds), because the awful music they've added doesn't improve the game, and actually gave me headaches. I recommend playing with your own music as a background, even if that mean you don't get the important "overcrowding station warnings".

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a puzzle game about stringing up as many different shaped stations in a line as possible. The challenge comes from the imbalance and numerousness of the spawned shapes, and your task is to figure out the logistics of shipping any cargo to its desired type of destination as efficiently as possible, without overflowing its spawn station, or any interchange stations on the way. The art style will be familiar to anyone who uses their local metro system, however unfortunately this game is not a simulator by any means. If you want to build any metro line in a way that vaguely resembles reality, you will lose and you will lose hard. The screenshots you see are only representative of the first 5 minutes of the game, they are not representative of anything you might end up with - There will never be enough lines or trains supplied to allow you to create anything orderly - your trains will weave around the map, twisting and turning to gobble up all un-connected stations like a nokia snake. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants an interesting puzzle in a metro theme. However I have to downvote it because the description is misleading - If you're looking for a subway management simulator, look elsewhere.

Posted: June 22, 2016
Mini Metro is a game of make-believe mass transit.Hear me out.Mini Metro allows you to build a subway system in imitation of the systems of major world cities.  The stations you must link up appear randomly within an area, and each station has a different shape.  "Passengers" are represented by smaller shapes.  Triangles need to go to triangle stations, and so forth.  You start with a few lines and you can connect your stations -your passengers can make transfers- and work around the waterways of the city.  You have trains (needed to make your lines work), carriages (boosting the capacity of packed trains) and tunnels/bridges (to work around the water).Mini Metro starts with London and Paris, and the other cities unlock, one by one, by transporting enough passengers on the city before it.  New cities bring new challenges and new resources. Mini Metro allows for brief play sessions.  I'm not particularly good at this game, so it's usually Game Over after about 20 minutes of play, which allows me to get up and do other things, rather than getting sucked in.  I'm getting better, I swear!If you played SimCity and want a briefer experience, or played Roller Coaster Tycoon and wanted something more... grounded... you should play Mini Metro.  I strongly recommend it, even at full price.  It's fun, and pleasing, but it is not exciting.  City planning rarely is.I bought this game for full price, I became interested in it after seeing it mentioned in one of the "Games You May Not Have Tried" episodes of Extra Credits.

												Don't get caught offguard by the graphics. Despite looking fairly simplistic, there's quite some depth to the game and the different maps. You constantly have to make strategic decisions based on the amount of bridges, lines and wagons you own to keep the stations from overflowing. On top of that, changes in acceleration and speed between the various trains and metro's make each map feel distinct.Eventhough you will eventually get overwhelmed, the pace and simplistic graphics of Mini Metro make it a perfect last game before bedtime. Posted: December 28, 2015
												If you like the adrenaline rushes that accompany micromanagement, this game is for you. As the one overseeing the construction of your metro, you are expected to strategize and be able to adapt to sudden and often unwanted changes in an attempt to move passengers from point A to point B.Picture this: you have a beautiful, stable system with no overflowing stations. You sit back, sporting a grin of pride on your face, until suddenly, one of your stations has changed and a new station has appeared on one of your tracks to ruin your delivery efficiency. As you scramble to tweak your lines, an army of circle stations all appear on one side of the map. And even with an entire line now devoted to these stations, you begin to experience multiple overflows. This unavoidable stress and the knowledge you gain from learning how to better construct your railways are the alluring charms that make this game so replayable.However, don't be discouraged by the inevitable-  the moment when a handful of people at an overflowing train station all collectively write enough bad Yelp reviews to put you out of business.

								Mini Metro distills logic and joy of multi-day train-route management games into a free-form art that can be enjoyed in 30 minutes.  Rather than work through tables of numbers or try to optimize the profitability of lines like a traditional train game, Mini Metro offers a lighter fair that encompasses the same core aesthetic without the complexity.  Suprising depth for a simple interface.I normally hold Early Access Games in contempt, as they are making a promise about a future game that they rarely deliver on.  Mini Metro's gameplay is functionally complete (aside from a sound to accompany the visual warning that a station is backing up).  I wouldn't care less if they didn't update another thing.

Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								A total time-suck, just like riding the MRT-3 in Manila! However, there are stark differences:Pros:+ You don't have to queue up for hours to get a ticket+ You never have to worry about smelly, sweaty passengers sticking their armpits just right up your nose+ You won't encounter snatchers, pick-pockets and thievesCons:- Currently has no audio*--bring your own music player (just like IRL!)- Currently has no achievements** (if you don't achieve anything riding the metro IRL, sorry but your life sucks)* Early Access review; they plan to add these features later** Feature has been addedMini Metro is a minimalist strategy-simulation game that's easy to get into but hard to master. Decide how you layout your lines, which resources you would actually need, and whether to take it step-by-step or reconstruct everything from scratch--all while making sure every one of your stations doesn't get overcrowded. There are multiple modes to play depending on how much stress you're willing to take. Personally, I'd take being stressed here than the actual MRT.

 Game is still in Development.  But you can see where its going. The Game is solid, if you like games like Civ, Anno and other construction / management games you should take a look. Posted: December 28, 2015
												If you like the adrenaline rushes that accompany micromanagement, this game is for you. As the one overseeing the construction of your metro, you are expected to strategize and be able to adapt to sudden and often unwanted changes in an attempt to move passengers from point A to point B.Picture this: you have a beautiful, stable system with no overflowing stations. You sit back, sporting a grin of pride on your face, until suddenly, one of your stations has changed and a new station has appeared on one of your tracks to ruin your delivery efficiency. As you scramble to tweak your lines, an army of circle stations all appear on one side of the map. And even with an entire line now devoted to these stations, you begin to experience multiple overflows. This unavoidable stress and the knowledge you gain from learning how to better construct your railways are the alluring charms that make this game so replayable.However, don't be discouraged by the inevitable-  the moment when a handful of people at an overflowing train station all collectively write enough bad Yelp reviews to put you out of business.
