Posted: December 29, 2015
												Mini Metro is a minimalistic casual game that's great fun. The goal is simple: you manage a subway system starting with only three stops, and see that it succeeds as the number of stops grows. Rather than being a subway simulator, the game is a simplified, more gamey version of that. Each week, you get additional resources (extra subway lines, passenger cars, etc.) to help you. The passengers keep coming faster and faster, stops will gradually be added or changed, and when you get too many passengers for too long at one stop with your limited resources, you lose! Each game is perhaps 10-30 minutes depending on how good and how thourough you are (you can pause time to lay down lines more strategically at any time). There are a couple different modes to change how difficult the game is. The gameplay is fairly addictive, and the acheivements add interesting new challenges to each level. Hopefully the Overwhelmingly Positive review rate also makes you give it a look.Also, it's great to play on a tablet!

												The game is addictive in part to the simplistic nature of it's graphics and premise. Posted: February 24, 2016
												Although I've played it a fair bit over the past few days, I can't fully recommend Mini Metro.It uses the theme of a subway and subway map, but the experience of drawing subway lines doesn't feel close to that. New nodes pop up sort of randomly and every day the subway gets a little busier, until a single station gets overcrowded. The mechanics, such as not being able to cross your own tracks, except at a station, and the fact that every train *must* stop at each connected station, make it hard to recreate traditional subway lay-outs, such as local vs. express trains. In the end, Instead of a making a system that's easily navigable, you're optimising it for mathematical constraints, and often end up with a sytem that's incredibly gerrymandered and Kafkaesque, rather than something a sane person would want to navigate.The result is that  during too few moments do you feel that you're running a public transport system, even in the abstract. It ends up a, somewhat interesting, puzzler where you're trying to optimise for mathematical constraints with a little "transport sauce" poured over it. Although the various maps have their own little quirks, almost none of them display true character, nor do the differences affect gameplay much, with possibly the exception of Osaka, where you get the use of "Shinkansen" trains. As a result, as it is, Metro Mini hardly makes a difference  playing London, Sao Paulo or any other city. You could just as well be playing on some randomly-generated map.All-in-all: an abstract puzzler with some limited appeal, but best avoided if you want some semblance of realism.Overall: 5/10The designers should've either gone for more realism, or ditch all the references to real-life and keep it a fully abstract puzzler. Now fans of neither genre get what they could have had.

Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Public Transport can be horrible. Especially trains. Most people say: "I can do a much better job at that!" Well, lets see if you canThis is a game where you control the London underground, exept it's not always in London. It could be Auckland, New York or even Paris! The developers - Dinosaur Polo - are always open for ideas, so if you don't like something (how?) it would be fixed.The controls can be a bit dodgy, removing a station for example isn't as easy as it sounds. You get upgrades every Sunday which allow you to:Add a carriage (max 3)Add a train ( max 3 I believe)Increase the amount of tunnels/bridgesAdd a line ( max 7, start with 3)and more!The game comes with 2 modes, with one coming soon:CommuterScenicRush hour (to be added)Commuter is the normal, standard, frustrating gameScenic, you can't lose. You get points by how many passengers use your metro per weekRush hour will probably be a ery intense commuter modeIn the game we have four types of stations:Circle (common)Triangle (uncommon)Square (rare)Special (very rare)Even though some are rarer then others, you will get at least one of these each game. The map is randomly generated however, so you never know where they will spawn.That should finish my review. I do reccomend this game and rating out of 100 would be:                                                                   97.5/100

Early Access Review
								This game can be summed up in a two words.Frustratingly Awesome. THe idea behind it is to create a mini metro network between stations, or shapes as they are in this game, and deliver the right shapes to their respective stations. The shapes will change trains, from one line to another until they reach their destination.You can stretch your lines aslong as you want, but be warned, doing so will decrease your abiltiy to collect passengers quickly as each line is limited to four trains.The challenge of the game is great, having to wait till the end of the week to top up your supplies is very challenging, especially when you get close to having all 8 lines running, those extra carriages can be lifesavers.I highly recommend this game, and if it can get any better Im eagerly awaiting the full release from the developers.

								What a great game.  Simple mechanics and gameplay, yet very addictive and surprisingly deep.  Great interface, very well designed.  I'm impressed and very much enjoy playing this game. Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just a crazy simple, beautiful, extremely polished strategy game.Place metro lines to connect stations that randomly appear as you play.  That's basically it.  You have a limited number of lines, a limited number trains and cars to place on your lines, and a limited number of tunnels to cross water, each of which you recieve more of as you play.  You can place and delete and rearrange your lines and trains as much as you want for no cost (and there is a tactical pause).  All you have to do is keep getting polygonal people to their polygonal destinations smoothly as long as you can, while the number of stations and passengers keeps increasing.Although the game is still in early access, this is really an incredibly polished game (the only thing missing is sound, which I don't mind).  It looks clean an modern and beautiful, it has a lovely UI and menu system... it's extremely clear and easy to use.  I've spent several hours playing it so far, and I definitely intend to play more... it is a great casual game - easy to pick up, with short self-contained sessions - but it also has some real depth.  You can put a lot of thought into your metro designs, or you can just throw something down and watch what happens.  It's quite flexible in terms of ways to play.  Each map/level/city also offers unique constraints and layouts (semi randomized each time of course), and the difficulty of the levels ranges from hold-my-hand to crushingly difficult, giving you access to all of them immediately, so you can explore your ability and comfort level from the beginning, and aspire to those harder cities.The only negative thing I can think of to say about the game is that I wouldn't want to sit and play it for hours straight.  It's more of a pick-up put-down game.  Also, there is no tutorial, and while the UI is relatively straight forward, understanging the princples of the game might take you a couple minutes and/or google searches.  Hopefully a tutorial will be added soon :)Highly recommended!  I think this has a lot of appeal for a lot of different types of people.

Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								You'll know exactly what I mean when I say that sometimes, you just want a fun, simple game that you can sit down and play for half an hour before daily life resumes. This game fills that role perfectly, artistically, and like it was designed for that express purpose. I find I can't really get invested in this game. I can play for a half-hour before I get bored, but that's fine, because that's really all I NEED to play. I can sit down, beat one of the cities, and resume my daily life.The game has you designing underground metro train systems for major cities, the likes of which include Hong Kong, New York, and Sao Paulo. The colorful little graphics are incredibly soothing, coupled with the calm background music. The game definitely does get frustrating at times, especially when you run out of bridges or your line doesn't work correctly. However, it teaches you to find a way to move past that. It's almost a puzzle game, but not really. If I had to classify it, I'd put it in the casual strategy category.I actually cannot think of any cons that this game has. It is early access, and man, for an early access game, it's amazing. I tend to associate 'early access' with 'broken, unfinished and poorly-optimized', but this goes against all of those stereotypes. I have found exactly zero glitches, and the game doesn't feel unfinished, - perhaps constantly-growing is the right word. I'd love to see more cities, maybe a bus element, I'm not sure. I'll leave that part up to the developers.]Overall, yes, I do recommend this game. And for the modest price of $7.79, why not?

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												It's a gorgeous Thursday morning. You're up earlier than usual, with a spring in your step and a song in your heart. You're daily commute lies along the District Light Rail, an overground train through the outskirts of London. Perhaps not the most spectacular view, but certainly a step up from the 'scenic' grey of the underground. You've arrived a few minutes before the train is scheduled, giving you time to glance around the station.You see a few people standing, arms crossed, seemingly scowling at the thin air in front of them. You can't empathize their gloomy mood; it's too nice a day. Far in the distance you see the train stop at the station before yours, but with only a few people at this station, you make no rush to stake out a spot.You realize your error much too late as the coming train pulls into the station. From end-to-end the rail is packed with people, and none are getting off. They've staked their spot to take them all the way back into London, with you stuck in the station until the next one comes. Of course, it is only the one train, right? Surely this one is only packed because of the rush hour commute. Your mood sours only a little as the train takes off without you, but your spirits are lifted by the rays of sunshine washing over the land....Several hours later, as you stand white knuckled and dripping with sweat, you pray this train will finally have some space. Your boss has called numerous times to angrily inquire as to your tardiness, and you fear your job may well be on the line if you don't show up soon. The station is now full of grumbling, groaning, greasy, grumpy Gus', and you bitterly realize you're just another one of the bunch. As you push back all the people clambering to the front of the line, you hear a horrified wail from the near end of the station. Your heart sinks rapidly as the approaching train audibly rolls into the stop, carrying with it what must be the entire London populus.The station, now eerily quiet collectively holds it's breath, hoping, praying that there is space for them on that train. The doors open, and to your surprise, the entire station politely lets off the passengers. Well, just the one passenger, actually. A lone man, who upon exiting the train notices the unsettling silence that has enveloped the station. He clears his way slowly through the throng of people who watch as he goes by, eventually reaching the exit and leaving them behind.A shout from the back of "IT'S MINE!" breaks the deadlock, and suddenly you and everyone else are clambering to make your way onto the train. The passengers already aboard are terrified, the train itself begins to violently rock back and forth from the wave of people crashing into it. Alarms blare in the din of it all, set off by the dislodging of the train from the tracks, but no one seems to care. It's not about getting to work, or making it to the restaurant for your date, or getting home before the kids set fire to everything. It's about getting on the train.A loud bang echoes from nearby, and screams soon follow suit. An elderly man, clearly fed up with public transit system set up, begins to open fire with a handgun. You seem him blindly firing into the crowd, hitting men, women, children, all like fish in a barrel. Time seems to slow down as you watch the carnage unfold, people dying right in front of you, family trees uprooted with a single bullet. You try to turn and run, but you can't peel yourself away from the carnage and terror that has taken place. As you take one last look at the shooter, you find yourself staring straight into his eyes as he pulls the trigger. And as the blood drips down your forhead, you notice just how pretty the sun looks when tinted with red on this goreous Thursday morning.So for all of you hotshot's who think this is just another game, remember: This is what happens when you let your stations get overcrowded. 10/10

Posted: October 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Easy game to pick up and play. No need for a tutorial, controls are simple and intuitive. Difficulty curve becomes a little steep once the game picks up, but sort of reminds you of old school atari games that just keep getting harder. Beatiful interface and the transitions are well designed.Complaints: - Some of the menu transitions or dropdowns are slow, and a little clunky (for example, clicking on the clock in-game to change the time).- No messages informing you of problems when placing lines. New players might not understand that they are out of tunnels, or why their line is otherwise being rejected.- No way (or at least no simple way) to choose the direction of a new locomotive. - New stations, especially well into a game are easy to overlook. If that isn't by design, a clearer sound notification or an outline or something might be of use.Commendations:- Very smooth feel. Hardly any "loading" or time when you aren't doing something.- Simple layout that still conveys all the info you need.- Calming, relaxing music that fits well with the game.- Variety of map options that mix up gameplay without actually changing the mechanics of the game.Has plenty of potential for community workshop maps. Also looks like it would only take a bit of tweaking to work great on mobile.The price is a little steep for a game with arguably little content. If you already have a game to play, might want to wait for a sale. Otherwise, go for it.

												I have played very little of this game (to date), but it has been sat on my Wishlist for 2 years, and I have known about it since just after the idea for Mini Metro was conceived.First of all, go buy this game.It is incredibly cheap for infinite amount of fun. Posted: February 8, 2016
												Simple: Draw metro tracks and choose how many trains go to each. No budgets, no construction time, etc.Calming: In normal mode, you lose once the metro stations start getting backed up. This prevents the game from getting hectic which makes it a nice game for destressing. It also has a minimalist interface with a calm sound scheme.Complex: While you could play it as a casual game, it's not merely a "casual" game. When I first started, I played it like a casual game. "New station pops up? I'll connect the nearest metro line to it. It'd look a lot prettier if the line was more symmetrical." You can do that, but you score in the bottom 25%. Then I realized, there is actually a ton of strategic depth to this game despite its casual appearance. Each time I play I realize new strategic factors in things that seemed like they didn't matter before. Now I'm in the top 10%. So, I think it's fair to saying it's more than a casual game. You can play it "casually" but you can also play it "seriously", analyzing every tiny detail.

Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stumbled upon this game when thumbing through the minimalistic genre. As it happens I have become quite a fan of it. Let me give a quick rundown of what happens here:* you select a map to play on* stations appear on the map* passengers appear at the stations with various destinations in mind* these stations all require the player to connect via transport lines* as time runs on, things get more hectic, more stations appear with more passengers..etcStations are denoted by shapes. Passengers appear next to the stations as a shape which tells where they want to go. For example a square station with a triangle passenger shows up you need to shuttle them to the nearest triangle station. As time goes on you will have many triangle stations on your map. The passenger does not care which triangle station you let them off on. This means the most efficient lines have all different shapes on them. Connecting a bunch of triangles together in one line is not really a good idea. Passengers that are waiting at a triangle station will never be triangle, so having the next three stations in your line be triangle is not efficient. They will ride the train until they reach their correct station, or wait at that station until the connection can be made by getting off on a station with multiple line connections that eventually lead to their destination. (basically like a hub station) This is where it gets tricky. The shapes on the map can change over time. Special shapes also appear that are rare. This means that you will undoubtedly have only one line that reaches a special shape. This will cause a buildup at the hub "interchange" station which for me usually ends up to be the square shape. There are many ways to play the game. Hopefully that short explanation will help new players get into the game.There are resources, in that you have a limited number of train lines, trains, passenger cars, and tunnels to traverse different map layouts that have bodies of water. You can also control the time by pausing it (which is very helpful later on in the game) or by speeding it up. It appears to me that both the stations and passengers at the station are generated randomly on the map. I am not that good at this game but maps generally last about 5-15 minutes before game over. It can get to be hectic toward the end of a round, where pausing and micromanagement comes in if you want to move 2000+ passengers before game over. This can be obtained by reworking lines, moving passenger cars and trains around, etc. You can even pick up a train and toss it back down in another direction if one half of your line is getting crowded.For a quick technical run down, this game appears to use the Unity engine, and currently uses less than 300MB of disk space. The game runs fine on Windows 10. The interface is clean and modern with large readable text. (thanks for that) The game users colors in an important way to denote lines/trains and includes a color blindness mode. The game is quite minimalistic from a graphical standpoint, using solid colors and thankfully has a night mode. Night mode dims the color palette which is amazing as I usually play this game at the evening hours in low light conditions. All good stuff here.I am no expert but here are some early tips on playing the game:* you can "loop" in new stations by dragging a nearby line to connect it* you can redraw a line by moving around either end of the line where there is a T marker* you can delete a line by selecting the color swatch at the bottom of the screen* you cannot cross lines when out in the open away from a station* trains and carriages can be moved from one line to another (you can even remove all trains from a line)* same as above and you can place the train back down going in the opposite direction* try to make sure lines do not have the same shaped station connected in a row* don't forget special station shapes and make sure multiple lines can see them* keep on the lookout for shapes in your line to change, this happens and can go unnoticed* spacebar key will pause and resume the gameC = circleS = squareT = triangle(the most common shapes are C and T, S being less common and specials not included into below basic examples)Example of good lines:  CST, CTCSTCT, TCTSCTCExample of bad lines: CCC, CSCCCCT, TSTCTTTTThe good idea above is to try and center the SQUARE station so it isn't all the way at the end of a line. It is a semi-rare station so on a long line it is helpful to have in the middle ground. Also note the rotation between common shapes, this allows trains to dump the passengers right off at the next station. The bad line has connections of same shaped stations together, with the semi-rare SQUARE at the far end of a line. It gets much more complicated as the game runs on but hopefully this helps explain the idea.Glad I purchased this game, and thanks to the developer for making it![edited in full review content]

Posted: February 4, 2016
A simple concept executed well...'Take passengers from one station to another before stations overcrowd and shut down' sounds so simple.  Add in the different shapes (types of passenger) and per-city limitations on the number of lines, trains, carriages and tunnels - and suddenly a simple concept becomes a very tactical strategy puzzle.The Steam Achievements have been well thought out - the first tier are pretty easy (Deliver X passengers in Y), the second tier vary from moderate to fiendish (for example, "Deliver 1500 passengers in Auckland using no more than two tunnels" has a 0.3% success rate so far) and will certainly result in some frustration... before you start another game anyway!It's a game that can be played for 15 minutes, or for a few hours at a time.  As well as the normal game mode, the endless mode allows you to focus on optimal configurations (as stations cannot overcrowd) and the extreme mode forces you to think even further ahead as you cannot revert changes!The random nature of each game is a mixed blessing - it provides replay value but occasionally will give you games that are frustratingly difficult (such as large clusters of circle stations together).  Thankfully those levels can be predicted early on so you can abandon them and start again if you wish.£6.99 / €9.99 / $9.99 might be towards the top end of pricing for a game such as this, but it offers considerable replay value.  Additionally, the developer provides a link to his Trello board in the news updates, which provides insight into what new features may be coming in the future.

Early Access Review
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: This review is/was written when this game was in/is still in Early Access. Think twice before buying/playing this game Ever since I was a young lad, I always was amazed with trains, especially with the London Underground, and Mini Metro does bring that sense of creating your own train system to life!Usually I don't buy early access games, as I feel that I am worried that if something happens, all my money is wasted. I also usually don't buy early access games because either they are unstable or broken and are not fixed or may cause problems. However, with Mini Metro and other early access games like Prison Architect, I really feel that Dinosaur Polo Club know what they are doing, they constantly update the game and the game is very friendly with its players.The game is not easy and can sometimes frustrate you with the way the trains work, however, it is a fun game to play and can sink many hours in gameplay time!The music (which has been added recently) is absolutely beautiful and the sound effects that play along with the music really rhyme together pretty well!Obviously this game does have bugs and some glitches, but through my playtime I have not noticed any bugs! In an early access game! Very impressive! The game runs very well, the presentation is really nice and I am very happy that I bought this game. This will probably my second and last early access game to buy!Well done, Dinosaur Polo Club! RECOMMENDED :)  THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!)

Early Access Review
								This game is simple, yet challanging. The purpuese of this game in my opinion is not to give the player a gigantic RPG like experience nor something to pour thousands of hours into as you master every element of the game. This is not a traditional game, by that I mean that you will most likley not call in sick one day of the week, buy tons of snacks and binge play Mini Metro for a whole day. This game is more zen like and works great with a podcast or an audio book in the background. I think what makes this game great is that it's a simple time killer, but what makes this game different from other time killers like Flappy Bird and Cookie Clicker is that it does not feel dumb. An enjoyable game many should consider having just in case they are waiting for something or have something to listen to and want something to do during the mean time.

Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Simple, beautiful, minimal, engrossing, inspiring.Mini Metro is a minimal, surprisingly relaxing, puzzle game. You create tracks between various different types of station in a bid to keep your city rolling smooth and efficient. Your resources are finite, and as your city expands you need to be strategic about how many tunnels you use, where you place junctions, which lines you put your trains on, how many carriages they have and the order in which your lines intersect different station types.Endless mode provides the most zen experience, with no overcrowding on stations, you can just watch your metro grow stress free. A beautifully minimal sound track sets the mood- again, zen. I have no experience playing this before the sound update so can't comment on what it was like before.

Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is like they read my mind when they wrote this game.  Do you also love trains?  And real-time strategy?  And modern design and feel?  Well, then this may be your perfect game too.  You get to play the chief of your metro system.  Draw the lines where you want and build the perfect system to shuttle passenger shapes hither and yon.  This has been exquisitely executed to resemble a classic urban metro map.  Hours of fun and many pleasurable challenges.

Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Way more fun than it has any right to be. The core gameplay (and stylish interface) is already fully intact, working as a somewhat abstracted city transit planning sim. The only major thing missing right now is sound, but in that sense it's perfect for podcast listening.

Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's a pure strategy title and by fully embracing their limits it does everything right. The goal is simple, transporting little passenger blocks to their desired stations. The UI is simple, dragging subway paths along the stops and adding carts on existing lines. At the start of every week you can choose between one of two upgrades. That's basically it. The depth? Surprisingly complex. With the ever increasing number of stations that you have to connect to your network and the ability to add new lines, the game gets ever more challenging. To solve this you can choose many different strategies, and even derive from real world subways. Star shaped, circle, checkerboard? Everything is possible (though not always efficient).The game is still in development and lacks certain important features, such as sound. If you don't mind you should buy it right now! Otherwise it is planned to be released in November 2014.

"Simply" put, it's a beautiful game. Minesweeper is simple, but if you throw yourself on Expert and try to get a score under 60 seconds, you'll want to pull your hair out.It's already a smart, fun, and beautiful game that shows promise of "taking you even farther" with it's awaited final release.

Posted: October 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not really sure what it is about this little indie game, but seriously, if the subject matter interests you at all, then I recommend you pick it up.It is, by far, one of the most compulsively playable titles I have set my hands on in quite some time. Even though it resides in the early access areas of Steam, it can comfortably sit beside others that are deemed to be finished. The only thing missing from this game is sound. That being said, the sound is something I couldn't care less about. It is the least of my concern as I continue to further the efficiency and optimal layout of my subway lines. The game itself is played through various stages, in this case, cities of the world. Each stage provides you with a basic layout map and routes or "lines" to place between stations. The stations are represented as shapes on the map that you must connect using your lines. As you do so additional symbols are shown on the map to represent the passengers.   Your locomotives move around the map autonomously along your set routes picking up and dropping off passengers as they go. This would present itself as an easy puzzle to solve, however, as the days and weeks go by in game, that couldn't be farther from the truth. It becomes a complex balancing act to try to get passengers to and fro as quickly as possible without allowing them to build up at an individual stations. This, as far as I can tell, is the only end game state. If a station has too many passengers, the countdown begins until finally the game notifies you of your defeat.The game is so simple and elegant, yet complex and harsh, all at the same time. I haven't played anything like it before. It sits by itself in a world of indie games that are increasinging in quality all the time, yet somehow all have a familiar feeling. This eschews that familiarity for something altogether different. Something playable, satisfying, and ultimately, something worth spending your hard earned money on to enjoy fully. If you aren't sure that you would in fact enjoy it, I recommend you go online and type in Mini Metro in your search engine of choice. There you will find a link to the developers "alpha" version of the game. It is very bare bones compared to what we have here, but it will no doubt allow you to get a taste of things for yourself. I don't think you'll be disappointed.Highly recommended!  10/10

												There's actually little for me to say about this game that hasn't already been said. It's elegant in its simplicity. Posted: June 3, 2016
												This  game has that simplicity and addictive "I'll play just one more" nature to it that all the classics (Tetris, Angry Birds, etc.). When you first run the game, you think it is doing a tutorial, and you are right, but then you realize you have also actually started your first real game. The learning curve is gradual and fun as the first game you play teaches you how to play. I have only played the London map so far, and I feel like I could play it over and over and try different techniques to figure out the best strategies--I cannot imagine how much more fun this will be when I try the other maps like Paris and Berlin.The user interface is clean and fun to look at--it uses the actual metro symbology of simple lines and colors and connectors to actually provide the graphics for the game and interface, all in one. Genius decision. As an added perk, you can save your games after you finish as screenshots and animated GIFs! Such a fun game!Some might critidize the lack of multiplayer, but as quick as the games are, you could make it multi by challenging a friend to the same map and watching them play. Even watching a game is mesmerizing!UPDATE AFTER 9 HOURS OF PLAYThis game is so awesome. I come back to it almost every day and play a round or two. I am trying not to go on to the next map until I have done 1,000 passengers...but this broke down when I hit Hong Kong, where I cannot get more than 500 or so. So hard! I went ahead and went on and lowered my standard to 500+ passengers per map before I go on, and so far I can hit 1,000 passengers on all of them up to Osaka, which I just played today--Osaka, which has a really fast train engine on it! I did not know this game had different engines later in the maps! This made an already addictive, fun, challenging, innovative, elegant game that much better! So good. When this comes out on Android, I will buy it again so I can play on my phone and tablet!

Posted: May 29, 2016
												[EDITED]Good puzzle game in which each level progessively gets harder. Like 'old school' games where you don't beat the level, rather you keep on playing to get as high a score as possible. It would be easy to think that the levels are 'samey' but I feel they're different enough for each level to have it's own challenge, have their own aesthetic and even come to have a favourite level.I would say that, personally, the background audio needs some working on as after you've lost a level it can loop on an uncomfortable pitch and won't change once you've started a new level. [EDIT] The developers have fixed this bug in a recent patch!Overall - 8.5/10

Posted: March 28
												Simple to get into, will keep you entertained for hours.It could use better explaining of a couple "advanced" mechanics, but you'll get the hang of everything in one sitdown with no problem. Introduction tutorial is wonderful to start.It works fantastic when you're on two-screen mode, probably the best I've seen.Controls are responsive enough, I've ran into minimal issues while redrawing lines but nothing worth detailing.Soundtrack/Art-style are minimalistic and personally I love the style, so I'm more than satisfied.Option menu is somewhat limited but includes everything you will probably need. Posted: June 24, 2016
												This is a puzzle game, above all. It's not a building game. Yes, the maps you create can look cool - but they need to be efficient. It's all about keeping your stations unclogged and running smoothly. But you also need to make sure you're using your tunnels and trains well, because you have limited amount. Thankfully, you can rearrange your lines after they're complete. It took me a while to realize that, so that's why I'm mentioning it. As for the cities, thedifference is the shape of the rivers and shorelines. These will effect how you use your tunnels. After a few maps, it does get pretty difficult.If you're looking for puzzle game with a unique theme, give this one a try.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												Beauty so often goes hand in hand with simplicity. Dinosouar Polo - the developers of Mini Metro took that ddesign pholosophy to heart. For starters, Mini Metro is a wonderfully minimalist game about owning and managing a Mini subway in a plethora different cities. Different shapes pop up, your job is to link these shapes together with lines representing railway lines in order to ferry passengers from staion to station.Sounds disarmingly simple? Well, in a way, yes it is: the colourful, flat graphics make information easy to asertain, the gameplay never change and to the mechanics are easy to learnd... and yet impossible to master. As your interconected railway gets more and more passengers youu must fight to make it as efficient as possible - as if a single station becomes conjested, your metro is closed and that's game over. To summarise, Mini Metro is a beautifully simple, easy to understand game that you can pick up for barely anything. It's basically Train Simulator for people who don't actualy care about rtrains and just want a caual, intuative, endlessly replayable puzzle game. Although, I must say, yu can complete the levels in a matter of hours and after that you're just retreading old ground. 8/10 - not enough train.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Mini Metro is one of those games that is just deceptively simple, and yet can be quite challenging.It's essentially a puzzle/simulator, with really simple mechanics of 'add some trains to lines' and 'get passengers from A to B quickly'. From the get-go, that doesn't seem very hard, but this game does a good job of ramping up the difficulty. By the time you've gotten to the more difficult levels, or are trying to complete the achievement challenges, you realize you need to consider a lot of problems and juggle lots of different possible configurations of lines and trains.The graphics and sounds in this game match the simple premise, and help to avoid distracting you from the simulation at the base of the game. I did find that this made it hard sometimes to get the game to do what you wanted, like going around a river bend rather than using up a tunnel by going through it, but overall it works well.Definitely worth playing if you're interested in transport/management simulator games.

Posted: May 29, 2016
												This game is infuriating. I can't even get through level 1. Extremely fun game, but I literally cannot, in good consciousness, invest my time into a round I know I'm going to fail.A single overloaded node, which can happen in a matter of seconds, will ruin your game. Avoiding this is absurdly difficult, requiring an immense amount of time invested in the pause screen, planning your lanes, which may or may not be worse than what you had before, only to be ruined once a few new locations pop up.I, no doubt, just suck at this game. But I feel like this needs something more to help players avoid that inevitable game over screen.A population per node, perhaps. People per second, heat maps, popular spots, whatever. Just *something* more to help during the planning stage.Regardless, this is a great game. I just wish I could play more of it.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is, hands-down, the finest first-play experience I have ever had from a casual game.  Mini Metro is an outstanding example of perfection in minimalism, and a resounding lesson that gameplay trumps all.  As of this date, there is no music, and the graphics are simple transit system line art.  In short, you could have knocked this out on a VIC-20 in your basement-- if you'd been this much of a genius.The concept is brilliant, and the execution is perfect-- but this is still early access at this point, so there's a bit of a level shortage.  That's alleviated somewhat by the several subtly-- but importantly-- different play modes.Also, there are not a lot of upgrades at this point.  There are only three or four limited, important resources, and they're all really major.  A handful of more subtle, minor-tweak upgrades would make things a bit more visually interesting, as well as giving you a few things to tinker with when you're waiting to see how well a major change plays out.Nonetheless, this is absolutely the best casual game I've played in years.  Highly recommended, and definitely worth the money.  The only real question is whether you will also want it on your phone or tablet, where I expect touch-and-drag would only add to the fun.

Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just a crazy simple, beautiful, extremely polished strategy game.Place metro lines to connect stations that randomly appear as you play.  That's basically it.  You have a limited number of lines, a limited number trains and cars to place on your lines, and a limited number of tunnels to cross water, each of which you recieve more of as you play.  You can place and delete and rearrange your lines and trains as much as you want for no cost (and there is a tactical pause).  All you have to do is keep getting polygonal people to their polygonal destinations smoothly as long as you can, while the number of stations and passengers keeps increasing.Although the game is still in early access, this is really an incredibly polished game (the only thing missing is sound, which I don't mind).  It looks clean an modern and beautiful, it has a lovely UI and menu system... it's extremely clear and easy to use.  I've spent several hours playing it so far, and I definitely intend to play more... it is a great casual game - easy to pick up, with short self-contained sessions - but it also has some real depth.  You can put a lot of thought into your metro designs, or you can just throw something down and watch what happens.  It's quite flexible in terms of ways to play.  Each map/level/city also offers unique constraints and layouts (semi randomized each time of course), and the difficulty of the levels ranges from hold-my-hand to crushingly difficult, giving you access to all of them immediately, so you can explore your ability and comfort level from the beginning, and aspire to those harder cities.The only negative thing I can think of to say about the game is that I wouldn't want to sit and play it for hours straight.  It's more of a pick-up put-down game.  Also, there is no tutorial, and while the UI is relatively straight forward, understanging the princples of the game might take you a couple minutes and/or google searches.  Hopefully a tutorial will be added soon :)Highly recommended!  I think this has a lot of appeal for a lot of different types of people.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												I highly recommend this game. It's really, really addictive and so simple yet challenging.The goal here is simply to keep your city's (from which there are quite a few to choose from) subway running. And by running this game means business, you can't just connect locations and hope the passengers don't crowd the stations, but you gotta react to the needs of the people, meaning where do people want to go from this spot and manage efficient lines.After playing this game I can finally appreciate what those architects in London accomplished. Before I always wondered (aka complained) about how many times one had to change lines simply to get from spot A to B, but now I finally get it. Life ain't easy for engineers when everyone wants to get everywhere in no time at all without ever having to walk.And in case any of the developers read this; having pedestrian walkways between stations in this game would really be awesome, you know, so you don't have to connect stations by tube, but could simply put shortcuts for passengers in the game, so maybe someone would actually take ten steps instead of crowding my circle lines. Sure, not likely many people would walk those ten steps, but not entirely impossible. I've seen people do it.

Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game isn't so much a transportation network simulation as it is a subtle puzzle game. The key to sucess is to not overload your lines with the same symbols next to each other because that will cause stations to be backed up. Make sure to stagger the symbols! (triangle-circle-triangle is good, triangle-triangle-circle is bad.) This is easier said than done because many times you will have no choice but to have four circles in a row on one line.The second secret is always retool your lines as you play the level. More stations are added as the game plays out, and you will find what worked for the first 300 passengers all of a sudden isn't as efficient and you have to clear the lines and re-lay them out for the next 300.There's a lot of strategy in this game, from how you lay out the map to what bonuses you get every level. I've just sat here and played through all levels for the past five hours and even went back and replayed a couple of early levels that I didn't do so well because I hadn't figured out the system yet. This is a fun game!This game is low on flash and high on substance, it's a must have for anyone who loves puzzle strategy games!

												I absolutely love this game. As a kid, I grew up with taking the metro in Washington D.C.  to visit the areas downtown. So now I get to make my own lines and help folks on their way to work, museums, or a restaurant. It feels very therapeutic coming up with a better strategy for every playthough; such as re-routing and upgrading the lines.Pick this up if you want a challenging but relaxing casual game to mess around in.You won't be disappointed.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I was hesitating to buy this game and kept it on the wishlist for a longer while, as it seemed expensive. When the Summer Sale came, I decided to buy something I really wanted to play. I felt like a transport sim, but Cities in Motiton didn't get good reviews, while Cities:Skylines were not cheap enough for me. Therefore I had only one choice within my budget and - to my surprise - It seems to be one of the best games for me in my collection!First off, one of my favourite games of all time are: - FTL - a more or less typical rougelike with significant strategy portion - Transport Tycoon / Locomotion series - where one of the main tasks is to build efficient networksCombine the two above and you get MiniMetro :).I'm a busy guy, and I don't have more than a couple of hours every day to play games. Therefore I turn more and more frequently to short games, that I can finish in a day or two, with high replay value. Mini Metro fits this description perfectly. Randomly generated stations are always a challenge (fourth circle or triange station in a condensed area drive me nuts!), while variety of cities encourage to try different strategies. I hope the descriptions will be added soon, although discovering the differences is also a kind of fun.One can look at the game as 100 years of a city growth condensed to 15-30 minutes. There are no resources - every "week" you get something to expand your network. It might seem strange, that you can re-rout your trains in any possible way. That way the creators avoided making the game extremely difficult - fortunately the "extreme" mode exist, adding that piece of realism for hardcore city transport organizers.With such minimalistic design, there is a lot of room for immersion. It's very easy to imagine that triangle and circle station represent every day destinations, like work/home/market. Square is probably a railway station or airport - unique but important. Then there is a bunch of unique ones, that can easily translate to a football stadium, hospital, or other touristic attactions. Even with no sound, you can hear all those crowds, looking at the train with six symbols - each representing a traveller and his destination.One of the best things about this game is the fact, that you are 100% focused on the core - designing the network as efficiently as possible. You don't have to waste more than a few seconds to build the route or add/move trains. If Transport Tycoon was simplified to a white board and lines with rectangles instead of detailed tracks and trains, you could finish the game in a fraction of usual time.Overall - GREAT game! I was not expecting that much from such small game.It's still early access and the devs are working hard to finish it - updates/hotfixes are frequent.FULL VERSION UPDATE: EVEN MORE AWESOME!!!

Posted: October 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Easy game to pick up and play. No need for a tutorial, controls are simple and intuitive. Difficulty curve becomes a little steep once the game picks up, but sort of reminds you of old school atari games that just keep getting harder. Beatiful interface and the transitions are well designed.Complaints: - Some of the menu transitions or dropdowns are slow, and a little clunky (for example, clicking on the clock in-game to change the time).- No messages informing you of problems when placing lines. New players might not understand that they are out of tunnels, or why their line is otherwise being rejected.- No way (or at least no simple way) to choose the direction of a new locomotive. - New stations, especially well into a game are easy to overlook. If that isn't by design, a clearer sound notification or an outline or something might be of use.Commendations:- Very smooth feel. Hardly any "loading" or time when you aren't doing something.- Simple layout that still conveys all the info you need.- Calming, relaxing music that fits well with the game.- Variety of map options that mix up gameplay without actually changing the mechanics of the game.Has plenty of potential for community workshop maps. Also looks like it would only take a bit of tweaking to work great on mobile.The price is a little steep for a game with arguably little content. If you already have a game to play, might want to wait for a sale. Otherwise, go for it.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is, hands-down, the finest first-play experience I have ever had from a casual game.  Mini Metro is an outstanding example of perfection in minimalism, and a resounding lesson that gameplay trumps all.  As of this date, there is no music, and the graphics are simple transit system line art.  In short, you could have knocked this out on a VIC-20 in your basement-- if you'd been this much of a genius.The concept is brilliant, and the execution is perfect-- but this is still early access at this point, so there's a bit of a level shortage.  That's alleviated somewhat by the several subtly-- but importantly-- different play modes.Also, there are not a lot of upgrades at this point.  There are only three or four limited, important resources, and they're all really major.  A handful of more subtle, minor-tweak upgrades would make things a bit more visually interesting, as well as giving you a few things to tinker with when you're waiting to see how well a major change plays out.Nonetheless, this is absolutely the best casual game I've played in years.  Highly recommended, and definitely worth the money.  The only real question is whether you will also want it on your phone or tablet, where I expect touch-and-drag would only add to the fun.

Early Access Review
								This game is one of the simplest yet best quick little challenge/strat/thinking/brainpower ect games I have played. you get stressed a bit, not to the point of a mental breakdown but just enough to make it entertaining. As this is early access I will be talking more aboult the con's than the pro's to help the curators along.cons:1 why doesn't it open in full screen in the first place. pretty much every body i know would put this in full screen, it is just more sensible.2 it didnt seem to auto adjust to the res this was annoying until i found you could change the res and fine tune it.3 the bar at the bottom was not obvious in daytime mode, and would be better if the handle was a different colour. Also i feel it should start locked so that new players can find it easily (like me)4 there aren't adjustable intensities. slowing down the rate at which "people" spawn would be nice for when you're tired and don't want to play on a full out fps and dont want the full stress of what it is now. options like "slow" "casual" "normal" "hard" "intense" would be great. if there are these they are not obvious.5 night time is WAAAAYYYYY better than day time and this option should be easier to find.6 changing line shapes can be annoying sometimes i had to completley undo a line to fit in just 1 more station. to be able to break the line at any station would be greatThat is all the cons I can think of so just remember that I focused on the cons. The gameplay is awesome even if it is very simple and is very addicting. It loads quickly which is awesome. it is nice and bright. it is simple enough to play when tired. and just get it. you will be addicted. AND ITS CHEAP AS CHIPS. All around an awesome game and I can see it really becoming something as it progresses.

												For a fairly bare-bones transport sim (you're only delivering passengers, although there is some managing of which station people want to get to, and good luck if you're playing Osaka and you run out of tunnels), it's surprisingly complex, and very addictive. Definitely worth the asking price, would not refund.From playing about 90 minutes, I think the best strategy is to make circle lines and connect them with main lines. But this tends to fall apart when the loops get too big to deal with the passengers, and you run out of lines, and oh God I think they're rioting.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												Efficency Simulator 2015, more commonly known as Mini Metro, is a connect-the-dots puzzle game where you try to get shapes from one shape to the one that matches them. Presumably the shapes represent what station the people are trying to go to.This game has a handful of things going for it, from sleek minimalistic design to the matching audio design, for the right kind of person this is a relaxing and therapeutic experience. If you find yourself panicking on a strict time limit, this game may not be for you, but for everyone else it comes highly reccomended.10/10 would connect the shapes with colorful lines again.

Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very fun little game. Simple but addicting mechanics. You control a city's metro system, you build different lines by connecting the "stops" which show up on the map. Each stop is shape-coded, and passangers want to go to specific shapes. I like to think of this as a kind of zoning metaphor, circles are residental, squares are malls, etc. But that's all secondary to the gameplay. Passengers are simply randomly generated at different stops, and your trains show up to take them where they want to go (hopefully). The map starts off very simple, and slowly expands and new stops are randomly generated. Every week you get a new train, and a semi-random perk. And that's it. At this stage there is a lot of room to build different modes that are more differentiated from one another, but as it stands a game that is very fun to play for easy quick gaming sessions.

Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm not usually a fan of early access games, but the minimalism present in this game really appealed to me. When I first played a couple of months ago, I was a bit disappointed with the lack of variety. There were only a couple of maps, which all played very similarly, and Rush Hour mode was not yet finished. When I started playing again recently, I was pleased with what the developers had done. More than double the maps were added, all which now play quite differently from each other, and Rush Hour mode was complete. At this point, it would seem the game is complete (minus the lack of audio), but it seems the developers still have a few things in mind.Overall the game is very easy to pick up an play. It's simple, relaxing and, despite being somewhat slow-paced, very challenging. I'm still not certain if you can actually "win" a game, but that doesn't keep me from trying. Highly recommended.

Posted: October 31, 2016
												+ Smooth interface+ Relaxing background 'music'- Repetitive gameplaySimple to learn, difficult to master, Mini Metro is a great casual puzzle game. Don't be decieved by the colorful shapes and soothing tones, however, as it becomes very tough the longer you play. This game is perfect if you want to chill out for twenty minutes, but can be easily obsessed over by the compulsive organizers and managers out there. If you aren't one to obsess, then you might find this simple puzzle game stale after several playthroughs, as each map has little to offer in differences. Each level has a slow statup as well, since you must begin with nothing and work from the ground up each time. But if you are a fan of simple puzzle games, as well as resource management, then Mini Metro is a great choice for you.

Posted: December 19, 2015
												Mini Metro is a revelation; it's been a very long time since I last played a game so original and addictive. Picking up the basics of the game takes moments, but the more you play it, the more you see the inherent depth in the game. The various playable cities at first seem very similar, but after a while you realise that each requires very different strategies. The minimalist art design is excellent. The use of smooth crisp, sharply coloured diagrams really makes you feel like you are creating a tube map. It's amazing how immersive such a graphically simple game can be.I have a few minor gripes; occasionally trains get stuck in the stations for no apparent reason. The random spawning of stations, whilst giving great replayability, can also sometimes make games unplayable. But these are minor issues and I hope they will be fixed soon,The game is a natural fit for tablets and I'll be interested to see a release there, and hoping this will see it get more attention. In my view a real classic.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												This puzzle game is surprisingly very soothing.  The music is procedurally generated and is mostly made up of subway beeps and tweeting birds.  When you hit the Game Over screen, the music just fades away as the sound of waves plays over the effect.  Aesthetically, it’s also very soothing, even though Colorblind Mode tends to put the most obnoxious yellow against a white background that makes it barely visible.  Gameplay is very simple and kind of therapeutic.  This is one of the few puzzle games where I didn’t find myself swearing at the game when they would change something up to make it more challenging.I definately recommend this game, especially if you want to play a low-stress time-killer puzzle game.

Posted: June 6, 2016
												I love this game. It's a puzzle that starts out relaxing and meditative and slowly, ever so slowly, becomes intensly stressful as crowds build and you desperatly watch the clock, waiting for the end of the week and your next upgrade to try and satisfy the rushing masses. Those masses are represented by tiny little geometric shapes, which indicate which stop they are looking to reach. Bonus points for how the acheivments are actually goals that make the game more interesting. Each map has two acheivments tied to them, one is the simple victory condition to unlock the next map, the next is a proper challenge to really push you to the limit. Anyone can ferry 500 people around, but can you ferry 1,000 with only one tunnel?Then, to keep you having fun, every day comes with a daily challenge map for everyone to compete for high score on.You need this game in your life. Trust me.

Posted: November 7, 2016
												This is only my second review for a Steam game, so that should speak to how I appreciate this game, I suppose.In short, I'd like to say that Dinosaur Polo Club has earned my trust as a game developer. I purchased this game when it was still in Early Access, and was impressed to see that it actually LEFT Early Access and became the game it was meant to be, unlike so many other titles I've seen in the last year.If you are looking for an adventure out of this game, then you are going in with the wrong expectations. This is purely an arcade-style strategy game, very minimalist in design, and it doesn't promise to be anything other than that. The thing is, it's really good. Especially if you're a casual gamer and just want to wind down a bit at night. (I really love the night version of the game. It gives you a black background instead of the bright white.) The audio is very calm. There is no music, but the sound effects were so well crafted that you will swear there is a gentle tune playing.It's a very simple game but can get incredibly difficult, so you may want to refrain from the more hardcore modes if you're  just using this to turn off and go to sleep to.If you are colorblind, this game is also great for you.My only con is it can be a bit finicky when adjusting pre-existing track routes. If it was a little less insistent on connecting to the station you are trying to disconnect the track from, everything would be perfect. Otherwise, I have no copmlaints and this game is simply worth the price.It's fun, it's challenging, it's easy to understand, it's relaxing, and it receives regular updates from a development team that actually seems to care. I have learned to avoid Early Access "games" (more like vaporware), but this is one developer I would gladly go Early Access with again.

Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Both cohesive and pleasing to the eye, this train game is not just another train game.  While this has been said of almost every train game, Minimetro, offers simple game mechanics with increasing difficulty that provide entertainment and a challenge for anyone.  Micromanage, in realtime, a subway system in one of the world's greatest metropoli. Prevent your stations from overcrowding in an effort to get all of your passengers to their destination.  Offering three gamemodes of varying difficulty, The game can be easily picked up, but will continue to provide a challenge for months to come to even the greatest strategist.   Certainly worth its value this early access game only lacks a soundtrack. Glitchfree and carefree this game excels!

Posted: January 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is good fun. But! You really have to be into the whole "city management/ efficiency" type gaming to enjoy it. Spawn points pop up for new passengers to be delivered. You must keep the rails/tubes from backing up or you fail (which isn't really a fail) It will ask you to continue or restart and you can rearange your lines.The objective is clear, but it is also endless.You are given multiple city layouts to play on starting with London, Paris, Tokyo and New York. Many more as well, I just haven't played them all. It is all click and drag. There are no hot keys, but the interface is very friendly. No music yet... (early access stuff in the works) Overall I very much enjoy this game. It's simple and fun to play when you just want to chill and listen to some music while toting aroung you pixel people from station to station.
